toc_family_titles: Note from the Publisher on the Second Edition

highlighted_text: This book and the DevOps community as a whole have shown time and time again that DevOps practices and processes can take even the most legacy-riddled, old “horse” enterprise organization and turn it into a nimble technology organization.
toc_family_titles: Note from the Publisher on the Second Edition

highlighted_text: In 2021, it is clearer than ever before that every business is a technology business and every leader is a technology leader. Not only can technology no longer be ignored or relegated to the basements; it must also be considered a vital part of the entire strategic endeavor of the business.
toc_family_titles: Note from the Publisher on the Second Edition

highlighted_text: The bottleneck of today is no longer just technical practices (though they still exist); the biggest challenge and necessity is getting business leadership on board. Transformation must be co-created between the business and technology, and the theories presented here can lead that change.
toc_family_titles: Note from the Publisher on the Second Edition

highlighted_text: Ninety percent of that work involves getting the right people engaged, onboard, and aligned.
toc_family_titles: Note from the Publisher on the Second Edition

become fully automated, solving many problems associated with the configuration and release management processes (e.g., keeping the configuration management database and definitive software libraries up to date)
because DevOps requires fast detection and recovery when service incidents occur, the ITIL disciplines of service design, incident, and problem management remain as relevant as ever.

While many of the DevOps patterns shown in this book require automation, DevOps also requires cultural norms and an architecture that allows for the shared goals to be achieved throughout the IT value stream.
